title: Why do gibbons sing duets?
intro: Listen to Rob and Neil discussing screeching monkeys, the songs that gibbons sing and the evolution of human language whilst teaching some related vocabulary.
this_week_question: How far can a gibbon's voice travel through the forest? Is it…
gibbons small apes that live in Southeast Asia
primates animals belonging to the same group as humans, which includes monkeys and apes
duets songs sung by two people
a close shave a dangerous or difficult situation you just manage to avoid
screeching making a loud, high and unpleasant sound
evocative brings strong feelings or memories to mind
cacophony mix of loud noises, which often sound out of tune
predators animals that kills and eats other animals
ancestor an animal – or human – from the past that a modern animal or human has descended from
evolutionary a gradual process of change or development

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Hello and welcome to 6 Minute English. I'm Rob…

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: And hello! I'm Neil.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Hi there Neil. Have you ever had a close encounter with a monkey or an ape?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Well I’m sitting right next to you, Rob?

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Very funny. Neil is referring to the fact that all humans are descended from apes, and apes and monkeys belong to a group of animals called primates .  The difference is that monkeys have tails, and apes don’t.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Well, I didn’t know that. On a serious note… I had a close shave with some monkeys once in Bali.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: A close shave is where you only just manage to avoid a dangerous situation. So Neil, what happened?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: I was walking up a mountain on my own and suddenly a bunch of monkeys jumped out of nowhere, blocking my path.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Oh goodness! OK. So what did you do?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: After standing there for ages while the monkeys screeched at me, I turned round and walked back the way I came.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: OK. If you screech at someone it means to make a loud, high and unpleasant sound. So the monkeys won that face-off , then!

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Absolutely! Yes, they did! And a face-off, by the way, means an argument or fight.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Well, today’s show is about gibbons and the different sounds they make. Gibbons are small apes that live in Southeast Asia. And while Neil’s monkeys screech unpleasantly, gibbons sound like they are singing.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Musical apes – that’s nice! So how about today’s quiz question, Rob?

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: OK, good idea. How far can a gibbon’s voice travel through the forest? Is it…

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Hmm. Well, I have to guess and I’m going to say b) 1km.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: You’ve never heard one.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Never heard one…

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: OK. We’ll find out later on in the programme whether you’re right or wrong. Now let’s listen to what a gibbon really sounds like.

transcript.author: Interview with Dr Esther Clarke, researcher at Durham University
transcript.text: Interviewer: Let’s just hear this. [gibbons calling] That’s an absolutely wonderful, evocative sound, isn’t it? Beautiful sound. And what are they doing there then? That is … I said talking to each other.

transcript.author: Dr Clarke:
transcript.text: Well this is their… They’re singing together. So a male and a female, when they hold a territory together, will sing every morning what they call a duet. All the groups…

transcript.author: Interviewer:
transcript.text: What we call a duet.

transcript.author: Dr Clarke:
transcript.text: Yes, absolutely. And they’ll all sing together at the same time, and the whole forest will be alive with this cacophony of song.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: So the gibbons make an evocative sound. If something is evocative it brings strong feelings or memories to mind.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: And something that is evocative is usually pleasant, Rob.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: It is. And what’s also interesting is that the apes are singing in pairs – one male and one female. They are singing duets together. So a duet is a song sung by two people – or in this case, sung by two gibbons!

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: And a lot of gibbons are singing duets at the same time – which Dr Clarke describes as a cacophony . Cacophony means a mix of loud noises, which often sound out of tune.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: And that could easily describe us singing together!

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Let’s not do that.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: But what’s the reason for the gibbon duets, Neil?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Well, the songs advertise the relationship between the male and the female. And they also help to make clear which territory – or bit of land – belongs to a pair or group of gibbons.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Gibbons also use different sounds to alert – or warn – other gibbons about danger from predators – these are animals that eat other animals. The gibbons use a quiet ‘hoo hoo’ call to communicate that a leopard is nearby, and an even quieter ‘hoo hoo’ call for an eagle.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: You’re very good at that Rob.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Thank you.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Now let’s hear more from Dr Clarke about this. How does she describe language?

transcript.author: Dr Esther Clarke, researcher at Durham University
transcript.text: Yes, so the idea is that if we find things like context-specific calling in non-human primates, it suggests that way back in time the ancestor that we shared with them also had context-specific calling so basically it just gives us some clues [as] to the evolutionary roots of complex communication like language.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Dr Clarke says that if we go far enough back in time humans and other primates such as monkeys and apes have the same ancestor .

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Right. And ancestor means an animal – or human – from the past that a modern animal or human has descended from. So if this common ancestor used context-specific calls like modern gibbons – then it could have passed on this ability to humans a long time ago.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Context-specific calling means different calls for different situations, for example one call for ‘leopard’ and another for ‘eagle’.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: And evolutionary means a gradual process of change or development.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: OK, let’s have the answer to the quiz question. Earlier I asked: How far can a gibbon’s voice travel through the forest? Is it: a) 500m b) 1km or c) 5km?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: And I said b) 1km.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: And you were right! A good guess! Perhaps you do know a lot about gibbons. So well done! Now, can we hear today’s words again maybe in a gibbon's voice Neil?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: I’m not sure about that. I’ll do it in a human voice.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Thank you. Well, that's the end of today's 6 Minute English. You can hear more 6 Minute English programmes on our website at bbclearningenglish.com .  Please join us again soon.

transcript.author: Both
transcript.text: Bye.
